original_title: Sri Lanka’s stocks edge down on selling pressure from financial counters
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edge down in mid day trade on Tuesday, with stable levels of turnover generated through selling pressures as the market continues on fears of domestic debt restructuring, an analyst said.
All Share Price Index was down 0.64 percent or 60 points to 9,345.90, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was down 0.87 percent or 24.20 points to 2,743.68.
“Banks are declining in value, scrip dividends and new shares are being listed, prices are being readjusted down which is why the counter is running on a decline,” an analyst said.
Top losers during 1200 hours were Sampath Bank, Commercial Bank and Vallibel One.

The Secretary to the Treasury has informed the Board of Directors of Sri Lanka Telecom PLC (SLT) and Lanka Hospitals PLC that the Cabinet of Ministers have granted approval in principle for the divestment of the stakes held by the Treasury Secretary in the two companies. However, the hype has died down for the share, not contributing to revenue like it would do.  (Colombo/April18/2023)
